STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 27, 2025
Kathleen Schultz
Wellspring Lutheran Services- Lansing
5826 Executive Dr,
Lansing, MI, 48911-5303
RE: License#: CB330371021
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 8/22/25. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the WOC area manager Shay Mavis at (269) 243-2725.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

children in foster home, Supervise

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
(4) An agency shall give a foster family a copy of the
signed current foster parent/agency agreement.
One of three foster home files did not have documentation that the family
received a copy of the current Foster Parent Agency Agreement.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as
follows, unless a greater frequency is medically
indicated:
(ii) A physical examination every 14
months.
One of three foster care files held an annual medical that was completed outside
of the required timeframe.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90 calendar
days thereafter.

Two of three foster care cases each held one late USP.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/22/24 Interim review, CAP approved 12/10/24
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Three of three foster care files held parent agency treatment plans that were not
signed by the parents or foster parents to indicate their involvement in developing
the plan, review or receipt of the plan.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The agreement
must be reviewed with the youth at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of one IL cases held an agreement that was reviewed greater than 90 days
after the previous one.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/22/24 Interim review, CAP approved 12/10/24
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Training documentation - The agency was reminded to ensure that Orientation
training has a breakdown of how many hours are completed for each topic to
meet the 16-hour total requirement.
• Training Rule 312 (3, a-o) - The agency was advised that the rule requires all
listed topics to be trained annually.

• The agency was advised that all findings of non-compliance by the agency
analyst will require a special evaluation for licensed homes. Even if the foster
parent corrects the issue while the analyst is on-site.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
One CAP was required as a result of the 11/22/24 Interim review. The CAP was
approved 12/10/24. The agency was cited regarding borrowed homes, late service
plans, missing independent living agreements, and required documents at the
closure of a case. The CA reported the agency successfully implemented their
2024 CAP. As a result, the agency violations decreased from nine in 2024, to five
in 2025. During the current renewal evaluation, two repeat violations were found
regarding service plan timeliness, and IL agreements.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) Assessment dated 8/19/25 was reviewed and
discussed. The CA reported challenges this year including staff turnover and a
decrease of quality service providers in the area. Despite these challenges, the
agency continues to function well and maintain compliance in most areas,
improving compliance in several areas from the 2024 CAP. The CA reported
frequent review of the CAP and action steps positively impacted their compliance.
The agency reported eight disrupted placements during this review period. Four
were due to foster parent request, three short term emergency placement, and
one youth moved to residential.
Financial Overview
The agency's 2025 budget and 12/31/24 financial audit were reviewed. No
financial concerns were noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. One staff had been with the agency for over a
year and the other staff had been with the agency for less than six months. Both
staff stated they enjoyed their positions with the agency and felt it was a great
place to work. Both staff noted they were currently lacking a program manager

and supervisor, which meant the agency director was supervising them in addition
to her other duties. Staff stated they were aware of the director’s many
responsibilities but felt that she did a great job supporting staff and staying on top
of everything. Neither staff had any concerns or suggestions for improvement for
the agency.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same building as the 2024 review. The
office had sufficient work and meeting space for staff, visitation space for families,
and secure storage for files and confidential information.
VII. AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
There were three identified safety alerts.
Safety Alert 1: During the 6/16/25 visit, the analyst observed the family's pool did
not have a self-closing/self-latching gate.
Resolution 1: The agency contacted the family on 6/17/25. On 6/20/25 the agency
provided a photo of the newly installed self-latching hardware. On 7/16/25 the family
installed self-closing hardware. Photos were provided to DCWL to verify resolution.
Safety Alert 2: During the 6/24/25 visit, the analyst observed the family had guns
stored in a locked wooden cabinet with a glass front. Due to the glass front, the guns
needed to be trigger locked.
Resolution 2: The agency provided trigger locks for all guns stored in the glass
case. Photos were provided to DCWL as verification.
Safety Alert 3: During the 7/2/24 visit, the analyst noted there was not a safety plan
for the family pool.
Resolution 3: On 7/7/25 the agency developed a safety plan and reviewed it with
the family. A copy of the plan was provided to DCWL as verification.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
_ ____________August 25, 2025________________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 27, 2025
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
WOC Area Manager
